comments.commentBody: This idea is convenient fodder for articles, but I have never actually heard one of my friends ever utter this phrase or talk about the concept. I think this is something newspapers think women talk about, but we don't. Almost all of my friends work and have kids, but none of them say, gee, i thought having it all would be better than this. We just perceive having a family and a career as "normal". It's what you do. Maybe that's a function of our ages - all around 32 - and our location - NYC. When we were growing up here that's kind of what you expected out of life - a career and family - and so we didn't have any illusions that it would be this out of the ordinary experience.

A doctor telling a patient that it is totally fine to wait until one's late 30s/early 40s to try to conceive a first child is so ridiculous it's practically malpractice. My husband is a physician and he's told me that the fact that fertility drops after 35 is practically medicine 101. Who are these board-certified physicians who say it's okay to wait until you're that age to conceive your first??

OK, so today I saw a rerun of "The Big Bang Theory" in which all the guys defeat Sheldon at a physics tournament by knowing all kinds of esoterica that normal people don't. They're still bickering at the end, so Penny sets out to "prove who is the smartest." She asks Sheldon and Leonard some trivia questions from game cards, the first being "Which sitcom featured the girls Marcia, Jan and Cindy." Neither had an answer. Then she asked "Who sang 'Oops, I Did It Again.'" Once more, no answer. (Brady Bunch; Britney Spears.)
Show ends.

Who out there knows what an ANOA or an ETUI is, but can't tell you what movie "Let It Go" is from?

First of all, I just wanted to mention that I did not post my other post about
"The Big Bang Theory" twice, so I'm not sure why it showed up in duplicate.

Now, about the puzzle. My main objection that the title, "The Descent of Man," gave the conceit away before I began, and thus, the puzzle was much easier than it should have been.

In order to ensure our ability to ascertain what is going on in the Middle East to protect our security, a balance has to be struck.

Those from the Middle East, who have chosen to work for our government and have sworn their allegiance to the US, may have to be reasonably vetted more often, due to their relatives remaining there and their other contacts. However, they should be given equal opportunity for advancement with everyone else, and not looked down upon as second class, in that their services are at the very least, on a par with our own nationals.

Our contrary actions could induce them to leave. And as far as loyalty is concerned, perhaps our own nationals should be vetted more often, like Edward Snowden. Regardless of his motives and our right to know, his actions have hurt us and endangered others working for us, more than those of anyone else we have learned about, including those who are the subject of this article.

They put those pieces of "art" up on the walls to recall features of the old Penn Station and then put the legend under the pieces "You are here."
Every time I see those, I want to say, "No! I'm not!!!"

I know a lot of people don't like the JetBlue terminal, but I think it's attractive (for a contemporary airline terminal), efficient & people friendly. At least has allowed the famous Saarinen TWA seagull building to survive, although no one seems sure exactly what to do with it.

I wonder if in the future, New York will regret the loss of another gateway to The City.  The once iconic Pan Am Worldport at JFK is now just a faded memory.  I know, that in recent years it was a dilapidated mess, but the wondrous rotunda should have been refurbished and incorporated into a new terminal.

I'm hoping that the city of New York will one day get wise and condemn that hideous 1960s monstrosity Madison Square Garden! Destroying Penn Station was surely one of if not the most stupid dicisons NYC has ever made. The wisest act would be getting rid of Madison Square Garden are rebuilding Penn Station in a dignified, neoclassic style on the original site. I use the "new" Penn Station frequently and the smell, dirt, crowds and mess of it really do make me feel like a sewer rat!

Agree with that.  Both the A.P. and the Coaches' Poll had Alabama and Florida State ranked 1 and 2.  One of them would have been given the national title had they won their bowl game by a decent margin while Oregon and Ohio State would have been the also rans.

Amen! Wish I read more about THAT in the paper, so that people can get informed and another tragedy can be averted. The renderings I've seen are nothing less that architectural vandalism! Gutting a building designed for the ages to replace it with a faux-Starbucks designed for the latest trends or glass cubes that can have billionaire's names etched on them is an utter dereliction of duty. Alas, that's what happens when the board of a venerable institution becomes laden with "new money" people who view the position not as a public trust, but as an opportunity to "show off" or "make their mark"!
I would hardly call Grand Central Terminal an embarrassment.
Still mourning the loss of the Donnell branch. Thanks for mentioning it.
Well, at least we still have the Port Authority to ennoble us.
Good thing Europe has everything figured out.  I'll stay here. Thanks.

"We shape our buildings and afterwards our buildings shape us"
Winston Churchill

Most current architecture is an abomination.

You're right, the New York City subway is really worse than many of the systems in the third-world -- the citizens of Santiago, Chile; Beijing, China; Delhi, India would all be embarrassed to have their clean, high-functioning metro systems lumped in with the decay of the subway -- a system that doesn't even have countdown clocks in all of its stations yet.

Change:
http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Bellows#/image/File:Blue_Morning_1...
Note that for the resume tests, the resumes were *identical.*  Large numbers of trials should remove the rest of the bias.

In what sense are African American names different from Chinese or Jewish names? Aren't ALL names given or used to "self identify?" Doesn't naming your child "Brendan" carry a meaning as much as naming your child "Jamal?" I suspect here that the problem is not the fact that certain names imply a social, racial, or political affiliation, but rather that the affiliation implied is associated with biases on the part of the hiring manager.

This does not explain why the highest marginal tax rates ever in the 50s and 60s drove the rise of the middle class. Productivity has gone up hugely in the past 30 years, but none of that has benefited the people who are doing the work.

We had higher marginal tax rates, yet fed govt receipts as a share of GDP (http://research.stlouisfed.org/fred2/graph/?g=W4u) and expenditures (http://research.stlouisfed.org/fred2/graph/?g=W4v) are actually higher now. Those facts do not square.

I highly doubt higher marginal tax rates will be tolerated in an era where capital is mobile, and the wealthy can move their money to tax havens like Singapore (Google Eduardo Saverin).

But if you want to turn the clock back to 1950 when there was less govt intervention in markets, from the environment to labor laws, lower overall govt expenditures, and tax receipts, I am sure red staters would be fans!
@dwb - The answer is fairly simple - there were so many deductions and exclusions in the 50s, nobody paid those rates.   The middle class paid about 20%, and the rich paid 30-35% in Federal tax.

So much wrong, so little time.

First, finance and insurance companies are busy moving south to places like Charlotte. There is nothing magical about Manhattan. Dallas, Atlanta, even Argentina are locations from which "knowledge workers" can work. Yes, we can outsource coding to Argentina, Belarus, or India. And, we do.

Second, housing is expensive because of restrictive laws that prevent denser development. Look at all the opposition to "pop-ups" in D.C.

Third, lets not conflate dollars with value. Just because "blue state" services are expensive, does not make them valuable. Oh, what would red states do without the services of highly paid knowledge worker Bill Bellichek and Tom Brady.

Actually, services are expensive relative to agriculture and manufacturing because productivity growth in services is slower.

Universitys are expensive because productivity growth is slower in education. We still educate people the same way as in 1200, in classrooms. Supply is restricted. That is changing with online and virtual classes.

Finally, about the value of the products of knowledge workers like CDOs, subprime mortages... fracking is comparatively environmentally friendly.

Why can't Americans admit that Europeans do some -- quite a few -- things better than Americans? If Americans were as negative and critical about their countries as Europeans feel about their countries, maybe they could actually solve some of their problems.

Passenger train travel is not doomed.  We have let it wither by not investing in it the way other countries have.  Nevertheless, the northeast corridor of Amtrak turns a profit and this is with all of the constraints under which it operates.

Not only have we lost the beauty of the original PA Station, the current mess is a disaster waiting to happen.  I am not so much worried about terrorism as fire.  If people cannot get around in the warren in the plight, what about when it would fill with smoke or flames.  I cringe every time I come in on Amtrak or take Jersey Transit.  There is no escape route.

find comfort in the fact that you're in good company...and we all have MBAs from prestigious universities and a ton of experience. perhaps we can all pitch tents together and live off the land somewhere.

@Query: the tendentiousness of the phrase "persistent rioting" had slipped right past me until I read your post. With that wording he gives himself away and robs his supposed admission of any shred of sincerity.

I'm a bit mad at myself for missing it - it just shows how seemingly casual wording can be inserted in order that readers may almost unknowingly absorb facts that ain't so.

This would not be out of place in Douthat's new year confessions of 2016.
